musicalLanguage.description: Bill Withers wrote this in 1972, inspired by the community spirit of his West Virginia hometown. The genius is in the simplicity — a gospel-influenced melody built entirely on the C major scale, harmonized with the most basic chords in music. No tricks, no cleverness, just truth. The piano part is central — Withers played it himself on the recording.
musicalLanguage.structure: 16 bars covering the verse and chorus. The verse (measures 1-8) establishes the gentle, reassuring theme over a I-ii-iii-IV-V progression. The chorus (measures 9-16) lifts with call-and-response energy. The whole thing walks up and down the C major scale like a hymn.
keyMoments: Measures 1-2: The opening piano figure — C-D-E-F-G ascending up the scale. This IS the song. Every human on earth knows this melody.
Measures 3-4: The melody descends G-F-E-D-C. What goes up must come down. The symmetry is the beauty.
Measures 9-10: Chorus — 'Lean on me.' The melody simplifies to repeated notes with gospel emphasis. The energy lifts.
Measures 13-14: The emotional peak — melody reaches up to G5 with the strongest dynamics. Community, unity, strength.
teachingGoals: The C major scale IS the melody. This song proves that the simplest material can be the most powerful.
Basic chord progression: C-Dm-Em-F-G (I-ii-iii-IV-V). Walking up the scale in chords.
Gospel piano feel: left hand plays steady roots and fifths, right hand plays the melody with occasional chord fills.
Playing with conviction: this song requires emotional commitment, not technical skill. Mean every note.
The ascending/descending scale pattern — what goes up comes down. The melody mirrors the message: we carry each other.
styleTips: Play this like you're in church. Steady, grounded, soulful. The groove is slow and deliberate.
Left hand should be rock-solid. Root-fifth, on the beat, every time. This is the foundation that everyone leans on.
The melody should be played with weight — not heavy, but present. Each note matters.
Don't add complexity. The power is in the simplicity. Resist the urge to embellish.
Slight swing feel — not jazz swing, more of a gospel lilt. The eighth notes lean, they don't rush.

measures.teachingNote: C major — the ascending scale begins. C-D-E-F: four notes, one per beat, walking up. Left hand: root-fifth pulse. This is the most recognizable piano intro in soul music. Play it simply, play it true.
Still C major. The melody continues upward: E-F-G. Landing on G with a half note — the 5th, the resting place. The scale has climbed from C to G. The ascent is complete.
F major — the IV chord. Now the melody descends: G-F-E-D. Mirror image of the ascent. Left hand shifts to F bass. What went up comes down — the song's philosophy in melody.
G major — the V chord. The melody rests on C — two half notes. The dominant chord wants to resolve. Left hand: G with D. The phrase has completed its arc: up the scale, down the scale, home.
C major — the verse continues. C-D-E-G: the same ascent but skipping F, jumping to G. A small variation that keeps the repetition fresh.
Dm — the ii chord. Melody descends F-E-D. Left hand: D with A. The ii chord adds just a touch of wistfulness. Soul music loves the ii chord — it's where the feeling lives.
Em — the iii chord. Melody: E-D-C-D, turning at the bottom. Left hand: E with B. The iii chord is rare in pop but natural in gospel. It's the scale harmonized, walking step by step.
C major — the verse ends. Melody lands on C and rests. A full breath before the chorus. Left hand settles on the root. Home. Safe. Ready to lean.
C major — the chorus. 'Lean on me.' Repeated E's with conviction — gospel call style. The melody doesn't need to go anywhere fancy. Repetition IS emphasis.
F major — the response. C-D-E rising up again. The call-and-response pattern: chorus states, verse material answers. Left hand: F bass. Gospel DNA.
G major — the energy peaks. Repeated G's (the 5th) then descent. The V chord under repeated melody notes creates urgency. This is where the congregation joins in.
C major — resolution. D-E resolves to C. The melody finds home. The chorus cadence is simple and definitive. No ambiguity. You can lean on this.
F major — the melody pushes higher: E-F-G-A. Reaching above the previous ceiling. The song is building to its biggest moment. The IV chord provides lift.
G major — descent from the peak. G-F-E-D falling back. The V chord supports the descent. Energy high, the arc bending back.
C major — nearing the end. The melody settles: C-D-E-D, a gentle rocking. Left hand outlines the full C chord. Almost home.
G to C — final resolution. The melody lands on C with a half note, then a whole note. Let it ring. Left hand: G resolves to C. The simplest ending for the simplest, most powerful song. Home.
